pros: Some good coworkers. The lower schools are a good perk and health insurance is good.
cons: The younger workers are lazy and the older workers play favorites. There is a lot of toxic behavior and poor salaries with no pension. There is also a lot of nepotism.

pros: It's nice when you don't involve your personal life with other staff members. The atmosphere is nice and laid back.
cons: There are some crazy people who work there. Anyone there could say anything to get you in trouble even if it wasn't true. If you get involved with a staff member who has a problem with you, they will tell the higher ups who are extremely gullible and will terminate you without hearing you out and a chance to appeal. So be very careful with who you interact with if you decide to work there.

pros: Cooperative, positive mindset and friendly environment
cons: need more policy to attract youngsters

review_title: Low Ceiling for Advancement, Outdated Professional Culture
pros: Laid back work environment. Meal plan included. Housing discounts. Unique school. Diversity and Inclusion. High quality food and water access. Meditation retreats.
cons: Disorganized leadership is ignorant at best, and enabling of toxic behavior at worst. Many interpersonal issues are swept under the rug to avoid conflict. The culture of higher leadership breeds a workplace without accountability where mediocrity is rewarded. Most decisions are made based on the perpetually dismal financial conditions and are nearly always short-sighted and entirely risk-averse as a result. For a school of people who have meditated for decades, the lack of progressive thought and policy is staggering. The younger demographic of the staff is steadily abandoning this administration due to their financially ultra-conservative stance on professional life. Room for advancement is nearly non-existent with most positions capping at $2k/month, permanently. Perhaps in 10 years or so when the older folks running this place can't do so anymore, they will realize the error of their ways. Invest in youth, invest in your successors, and maybe you will stop losing good people. Maybe you can prevent the school from a destiny where they only people who stay are the desperate and sub-par performers. Young people are not excited about the retirement home vibes on campus either - investment in infrastructure and facilities is desperately needed.

review_title: corrupted by a satanic racist s and controlling policies
pros: The original virtues- of Veda’s and Maharishi
cons: Oh there’s a lot- “Satanism “

pros: The job was relatively stress free. I got to work on a number of projects in the endowment office, I was given autonomy, and everyone seemed to value what I brought to the table. My hours were good (10am-5pm).
cons:
My boss was a black hole, any emails I sent to him were never responded to. Meetings were the name of the game, the bigger the group, the better. Decisions took far too long to be made. 

My pay was pretty low, even with included benefits, averaging ~ $15/hr, yet that was still higher than some long-term staff made.

pros: Close community, Everyone know everyone, Easy and old fashioned style of working, Slow and mostly easy networking. Low pay though and no innovation required at all.
cons: Indian culture is you can adopt its good for you, they follow, celebrate and teach every Indian culture /religion thing they can in the name of science. Old people with almost no vision works. Old professors, old deans, old town, old buildings, old infrastructure, old dressing, if you can take this all MUM is place for you. Forget about innovation and new things because it need to go through old brains which will put you on hold forever. Salaries are lowest, ran by old professors who never listen new ideas. No structure of formal education, you need to put off your shoes in going into different building , again Indian culture. Indian culture prevailed so much that whole university runs over gossips and talks. Immature old people ruining future of youth.

review_title: It’s a bit bizarre coming from a state uni
pros: They were very accommodating, very helpful, very kind. They’re all SO into meditating. They say they don’t have a religion. But they do. You have to drink the koolaid. The housing was very nice. The food was very good with SO many options. I was so surprised. It’s all organic too! You can visit for a weekend for $35 and they’ll reimburse your travels up to $350 about 3-4 weeks after your visit if you want to see the place for yourself.  They are conscious based education so they meditate and chant Vedic mantras before everything they do as it’s their big religion. They’re definitely sun worshippers. They have large classrooms. They had professors with phds from Harvard, Stanford, and Yale and top state universities. They’re not stupid people, they’re highly intelligent. They just weird about their religion. For me, i don’t believe it, but to each their own I guess.  The town has Muslim, Jewish, Christian, and Baha’i religious centers and gas staations and coffee. The uni has a small grocery store and coffee shop too in the student center by the dining hall. They really worked hard on the university but I don’t know if it’s accredited. I’m not sure. They did have advanced calculus 3 and algorithm computer science courses. They have it all on their website.
cons: They’re probably a cult. But harmless. They’re just kind of weird about their religion. But nothing dangerous.

pros: If you like working at a place where mediation (i.e. sitting on your behind doing nothing) is more important that getting things done. Slow pace of life.
cons: You have to drink the kool-aid. It is a guru worshiping, white-washed watered down Hindu cult that believes they will literally stop wars by hopping on their butts and self-hypnotizing. They have a King that lives in a golden palace of "world peace". So that explains where all the money goes... Extremely racist and sexist organization. Research TM Movement yourself and avoid like the plague.

review_title: It'd be a better place, if they dropped the dogma and the pettiness.
pros: Quiet, vegetarian-friendly and a nice calm environment to work. lots of rest with the mandated meditation and 'retreats.'
cons: Dogmatic and biased, not very open to alternative viewpoints, or worse, student opinions and desires for their education. Feigned interest in improving the world met by harsh reality of their trademarked programs being unsuccessful. Very isolated. 2 hours to an airport to leave the midwest.

pros: Here everybody is NICE with plenty of time to sit in the Domes to meditate.
cons: Unless you are a Governor i.e. take courses costing thousands of dollars to become a TM teacher, do not even think of  advancing in your professional career or earning a decent living. I never got my 403(b) though promised which unfortunately I came to know after I left the organization after almost 6 yrs of being a faculty. There is no policy in place for retirement, advancement in career. Departmental promotions seems to be arbitrary or dependent on who knows who. I have had the misfortune of my researches being stolen and published by another faculty who was incidentally rewarded though it was brought to the notice of the top management and the department.Almost 50% of the revenue is sent to India to support " Pandit" groups.The Board members are permanent - selected either by paying a ransom or by dint of sheer luck of being chosen by Maharishi himself before he passed away.The faculty are expected to donate large sums of money (even though they are paid a pittance and hardly any benefits) to uphold the values of TM and support the Maharishi movement which apparently is controlled by Maharishi's nephews. Very large sums of money are siphoned off to India on a regular basis for various projects which never see the light of day. the Faculty and students are kept under strict vigilance and anyone who raises a voice of dissent is quietly manipulated out of the university or program. The university pays thousands of dollars to counter negative comments about the top management which they could easily use to better the life of the faculty which they promise but never follow through.
